div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7105 ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JANUARY 24, 1905. SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
VLADIMIR’S DAY. BRITISH NAVAL MANŒUVRES. TSAR IN HIDING. DOCKYARDS ON FIRE.
div.p: ESTIMATED KILLED- 2,000.

div.head: GENERAL STRIKE AT MOSCOW.
div.p: Yesterday is known as “Vladimir’s Day,” being the name of the Tsar’s uncle, the Grand Duke Vladimir, a notoriously violent reactionary, to whom his Majesty confided the maintenance of order.
The exact whereabouts of the Tsar is unknown. The information is carefully concealed.

The ruthless firing on unarmed crowds has horrified the public. On all sides one hears scathing comparisons between the bravery of the military against the defenceless public and their conduct in Manchuria.
Inie former mutual distrust between the educated reformers and the workmen has vanished.
The novelist Maxime Gorki, addressing a meeting of Liberals associated with himself and Father Gapon, said that the revolution had commenced and would continue.

Father Gapon, who is unhurt and in hiding, has written to his comrades saying : “We have now no Emperor, innocent blood lies between him and the people. Hurrah for the beginning of the people’s battle for freedom. I will be with you this evening.”

The proceedings last night at Vassili Ostrow are still shrouded in mystery. It is reported that the troops invaded the quarter shooting and sabring every one they met. Some estimates give the casualties as 2,000 killed and 5,000 wounded. No official statement has yet been issued on the subject.
Large fires have broken out near the Warsaw Railway Station.
People are amazed at the colossal blunder

of the Government in neglecting such an opportunity for strengthening the people’s affection tor the autocracy. Millions of workmen have been added to the ranks of the intellectual malcontents.(Reuter.)
(Official). Until yesterday at 8 o’clock there were 76 killed and 233 wounded. The centre of the city is quiet this morning, but ferment continues in the outlying quarters. (Reuter.)
Sevastopol, January 23.
The vast dockyards here are on fire. (R.)
The morning was quiet, but about 5 o’clock the troops again fired on the people who were assembled on the Newski Prospect.
Some electric light employés have struck. The city is partly in darkness.
Independent observers estimate that yesterday’s casualties are far beyond the official figures. (Reuter.)
The workmen here have proclaimed a general strike for the 26th inst.
Householders are alarmed and are arming. The people are clamouring for news from St Petersburg, which the censorship is stopping.
(Reuter.)
The morning was quiet. Patrols are preventing people from gathering.
Captains Davidoff and Kazefi, who were in command of the saluting party on the 19th inst., have been arrested.
In the evening, fresh collisions took place on Newsky Prospective.
One regiment refused to leave in order to put down the riot at Riga. (Havas.)
A fire has broken out at the dockyards of the Admiralty. (Havas.)
The workmen of numerous works have gone on strike. (Havas.)
The newspaper telegrams state that 2,000 people have been killed at St. Petersburg. (H.)

div.head: FRENCH MINISTRY.
U.S.A. AND SAN DOMINGO. SIGNING OF TREATY.
div.p: The United States and the Republic of San Domingo have signed a treaty by which the former establishes a financial tutelage over the latter, at the same time guaranteeing her territorial integrity, (Reuter.)

div.head: BRITISH NAVAL MANOEUVRES. WORLD-WIDE PARTICIPATION.
div.p: The Admiralty announces that the English fleets throughout the world will participate in the 1905 manœuvres on a war basis, in order to test the strategic efficiency of the recent re organisation. (Reuter.)
The Reunion des Familles Society are giving their second ball of the season at Monferrato's Hall on Saturday next.

div.head: Wife Murder
div.p: A native clerk living at Gabbari yesterday killed his wife by dealing her a blow on the head with a bar of iron. The man escaped and his whereabouts is unknown.

div.head: A Fatal Accident
div.p: occurred near Demer dache on Sunday, when the ghaffir who was attached to the Princess Fatma Hanem’s property was run over and killed by the Pont Limoun-Marg train.

div.head: The Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. “Schleswig,”
div.p: which arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Marseilles and Naples, brought 91 first-class and 17 second-class passengers, who left for Cairo by special train.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 20th inst., 8 of which were British, 2 Dutch, 1 Austrian, 1 Danish. The day’s receipts were frs. 277,708.22. From the 1st to the 20th inst. the total amount received in dues was frs. 7,320,330.20.

div.head: Fire at Telephone Office
div.p: At about 10 o’clock last night a fire broke out in the telephone central office at Kom el-Dik, which caused a complete interruption of the lines connected with this office. The Telephone Company inform us that they will re-establish communication as early as possible.

div.head: Prize Distribution
div.p: The third annual distribution of prizes to Mrs. Emily Elliott Anastes’s pupils takes place this year to-morrow in Mr. G. B. Alderson’s garden, commencing at 4 p.m. punctually. Prizes will be given by the Rev. Canon and Mrs. Ward. Judging by the prettily got-up programme received, a treat is in store for those invited.

div.head: Abbas Helmy Theatre
div.p: As was to be foreseen, Sig. Gravina, the clever comedian of the Italian operetta company, had a most successful benefit night yesterday, when Santarellina, in which he is inimitable, was performed. The large audience was kept in roars’ of laughter by Sig. Gravina’s antics throughout the evening. The other performers also did well.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society
div.p: A meeting of this society will be held at the School of Medicine, Kasr-el-Ainy, Cairo, to-morrow, when Mr. Craig will read “Some notes on a visit to Entebbe,” with lantern demonstration, and Dr. Elliot Smith will read a paper on “Some new facts concerning the superiority of the human brain.” Dr. Elliot Smith will also show a cast of the brain of the okapi. This meeting is open to anyone who cares to attend.

div.head: Cercle Khédivial, Alexandria
div.p: The annual general meeting of members of the Khédivial Club was held yesterday evening, Mr. Robert J. Moss in the chair. The balance sheet of 1904 was submitted and unanimously approved and passed. The ballot for committeemen for 1905 gave the following result : Messrs. Robert J. Moss, Adr. R. Giro, Hassan Mohsen Pasha, J. R. Aghion, A. Bim-senstein, Paul Cavafy, A. Cesana, A.v. M. Colucci, Ed. Friedheim, F. C. Haselden, Av. M. Romano, Em. Stross, Av. Alfred Tilche, Dr. A. M. Ruffer, J. R. Reeves, Av. C. Castro, H. J. Lancashire, and H. R. C. Blagdeu.

div.head: All Saints’ Church, Ramleh
div.p: The annual general meeting of the congregation was held at the Parsonage, Bulkeley, on Saturday last, Canon Ward in the chair. The aocounts for 1902 were passed and Messrs. C. A. H. Alderson, K. P. Birley, hon. treasurer, and W. R. B. Briscoe, hon. secretary, elected as the committee for 1905, with Mr. W. P. Chataway as supplementary member Mr. James Hewat, who received a vote of thanks for his honorary audit of the accounts, was again elected auditor. Votes of thanks were accorded to Mrs. R. J. Moss for her gifts to the church during the past year, to Canon Ward for taking the chair, and to the outgoing committee.

div.head: Keiserlich Deutches Konsulat. BEKANNTMACHUNG
div.p: Jm diesseitigen Handelaregiater ist bei der Komrranditgeaellachaft R. Kuater A Co. eingetragen wo den :
Die G. sellechaft ist aufgelost. Die Firma ist erloachen. Die Prokura dee Kaufmann Harry Ablitt in Alexandrie ist erloschen.
Alexandrien, den 23 Januar 1905.
Der Kaiserhche Konsul.

div.head: THE DUKE OF CONNAUGHT. ARRANGEMENTS FOR ARRIVAL
div.p: T .R. H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught are expected to reach Alexandria on board H. M. S. “Essex" on Thursday morning probably about 11 o'clock, and will at once leave tor Cairo, where they are due to arrive about 4 o'clock. As before stated, their Royal Highnesses will proceed to Abbeen Palace where they will be the guests of the Khedive.

On Thursday night H. H. the Khedive will give a banquet at Abdeen Palace in honor of T. R. H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught The Princes of the Khedivial Family, the Ministers, Lord and Lady Cromer, the foreign diplomatic Agents, and the personnel of the British Agency have been invited.

Their Royal Highnesses will leave Cairo on the following night for Khartoum, and their programme up river will probably be as before stated, but it has been decided that the Royal party will make their own arrangements, while Nhugovich Bey will cany out all the necessary arrangements during their stay in Cairo both this week and on their return.
The following is published in Army Orders :
His Royal Highness the Inspector General of the Forces is expected to reach Alexandria and Cairo On 26th inst.

" He will be met on landing at Alexandria by the Brigadier General Commanding, Commanding Officers, Hoads of Departments, at Alexandria, and a Guard of Honor, consisting of 1 Captain, *2 Subalterns, a duo proportion of Sergeants, and 100 rank and file, with the King's Colour and Band, to bo detailed by the Brigadier General Commanding, Alexandria

“ He will be met at Cairo railway station by the General Officer Commanding in Egypt, Commanding Officers, Heads of Departments, in Cairo, and a Guard of Honor, consisting of l Captain, 2 Subalterns, a due proportion
of Sergeants, and 100 rank and tile, with the King's Colour and Band, 2nd Bn. Royal Inni-skilling xxxxx."

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will receive Prince Arfat ed Dawlah Khan, Persian Ambassador at Constantinople, at Abdeen Palace to-day and will return the Prince’s visit at the Continental Hotel.
His Highness has been graciously pleased to bestow the following decorations :
Medjidieh -Grand Officer (2nd class) M. George Zervudachi, notable of Alexandria.

Commander 3rd class) ; Soliman Zeitoun Bey. Omdeh of Kafr-el Hamam, M. Miltiadi Avierni, and M. Charies Bacos, notables of Officer (4th class) M. John Zoucas, engi- Osnianaeh Officer (4th class) Youssef Zouhny Bey and Ahmad Rifat Bey, notables

div.head: EGYPT'S PROSPERITY.
div.p: The value, in Egyptian pounds, of specie declared at the Egyptian Customs during 1094 was as follows :
Gold Imported, L E. 7,042,949.
Silver Imported, ,, 593,915.
Gold Exported, „ 2,724,157.
Silver Exported, „ 6,733.

These figures are very significant of the extraordinary prosperity of the country, no less than L É. 4,288,792 having been added to the net wealth of the country in specie alone during the last twelve months.
A. L M & D. S.

It would really have been difficult to devise a more attractive programme than that which has been arranged for the recital to be given to morrow evening at Mon-ferrato's - Hall by Mr. H. Scott-Leslie under the auspices of the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society. The versatile entertainer will contribute the following items : Musical monologue, " The Lesson of the Water Mill," humorous sketch, “Matilda and the Builder (The Girl from Kay's), character sketch, "E can't take a roise out 'o oi,” a dissertation on mediaeval poetry, “Taffy was a Welshman," a ghost story, the following song», "The Horse the Missus dries the clothes on."
Nothing New," "Something quite original,"

‘ He J. Hann, “I'm tired," and short stories. He will be supported by Mr. David W. Norton pianist) and members of the society. Mr. Norton will play Rachmaninoffs Prelude—C. Diez. Minor, selections from The Country Girl, and the solo, "lmperial Patrol." Miss Mun-Gavin will sing "Voices of the Past” and ' Beloved, it is Morn, ’ with violin obbligato by Miss Gibson, Mr. R. M. Nixon will contribute ‘The Outpost's Vigil" and "Blow, blow, thou Winter Wind," and some members of the choral union will give the madrigal “True Love" from The Cingalee and the glee, "The Old Norse Song." With such a plethora of talent, the hall should be filled to its utmost capacity. Messrs. Davies Bryan & Co. are selling non members' tickets at P.T. 15.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Cunard S.S. “Cypria” will arrive on Thursday and will immediately begin loading for Liverpool and American ports.
The Moss liner “Amas is" arrived at Liver-pool yesterday morning.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel In Alexandria. Facing the sea Jentral position. Under English management

div.head: SACRILEGIOUS THEFT. LE. 8,000 STOLEN FROM HOLY CARPET'S ESCORT.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
This year’s pilgrimage has already met with a most unfortunate contre-temps, even | before the Mahmal has left Egyptian territory.
I learn that a case of specie belonging to the I Mahmal, and valued at L B. 8,000, was stolen yesterday on the train near Genife station.

div.head: ARRIVAL AT SUEZ
div.p: The special train conveying the Holy Carpet t arrived at Suez at 3 o'clock this afternoon, and on arrival of the train at the station, a saluté of 21 guns was fired from the fort. Thousands of pilgrims, mingling with the natives of Suez, paraded the streets with flags, and the town presented a lively aspect

At about 4 o’clock the procession of the Holy Carpet took place. It was escorted by cavalry, infantry, and artillery, numbering 407 officers and men, under the command of Miralai Mohamed Bey Rifaat, as well as by detachments of Coast Guards, and the military band. Towards evening the Mahmal was con-veyed to the docks by the same special train, to be placed on board the Khédivial steamer ' Rahmanieh," which is due to sail on Wednesday for Jeddah.
This is a record year for the pilgrimage on account of the large number of Egyptian pilgrims, which exceeds 16,000, as against
12.000 last year.
The pilgrims are conveyed by the Khédivial steamers to Tor, where they purge five days' quarantine, and thence the same company’s steamers carry them on to Jeddah.

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LTD.
div.p: The rush of investors yesterday to subscribe to the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Limited, was extraordinary. All day long the National Bank of Egypt was besieged by masses of people, with the result that the amount tendered for subscription in Egypt was» £3,150,000, whereas the total capital of the company is only £200,000.
The amount over-subscribed in London is also very large.
Owing to this rush there will necessarily be some delay in the allotment

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND INVESTMENT CO.
div.p: The Egyptian Land Investment Company is one of the latest of the many similar ventures, which are being daily launched at Alexandria. It objects are described as follows

L'achat et vente do terrains à bâtir, propriétés baties ou biens ruraux en Egypte ou au Soudan, ainsi que toutes affaires ou opérations, dont le caractère ou le but serait de nature à faire valoir ses acquisitions ou a contribuer au développement des affaires immobilières en général.
The capital is LE 100,000, divided into 20.000 shares of LE 5 each, which have all been subscribed by the following:—
Shares LE
A. Bartau Pasha 16,200 81,000
Ismail Pasha Kamel Yaken 1.000 5,000
Kalil Pasha Kayat 600 3,000
Augusto Luzzatto 500 2,500
Tigrane Gamsaragan 1,000 5,000
Michel Reizian Bey 200 1,000
Yrvanthe Agathon Bey 200 1,000
Emanuel Stross 300 1,500

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.
div.p: The annual general meeting of members of the British Chamber of Commerce will be held in the offices of Messrs. Carver Bros & Co., Ltd., Alexandria, on Tuesday, 7th February, at 4 p.m.. The following business is to bo transacted :—
1 To pass the accounts and balance sheet for 1904.
2. To receive the committee's report of the past year's work.
3 To fill vacancies in the committee.
4. To consider a proposal to alter No. 5 of the articles of association By the following additions :—

A committee of 12 shall bo elected by the Cairo members to sit in Cairo, subject to the rules which govern the Alexandria committee. Minutes of the Alexandria and Cairo committees to be exchanged and the Alexandria committee to remain the executive.

div.head: CAIRO RACES.
div.p: By kind permission of Lient-Colonel G. M. Mackenzie, commanding, and officers, 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme at the Cairo races to morrow afternoon :
March—"Tho Thunderer”—Sousa.
Overture “Stradolla”—Flotow.
Entr'acte—“Rose Mousse”—Bose.
Selection—“Reminiscences of the Plantation"
—Chambers.
Valse—“Amoretten Tanze"—Gnng'l.
Song—“A Child's Song of Hope"—Myddleton. Morceau—"La Lettre de Manon"—Gillet Selection—"A Country Girl"—Monckton.
Regimental March.
Khédivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
R. Watson Ramsey, Bandmaster,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir John Maxwell left London last week for Egypt where he will join the Duke of Connaught. He has not been in Egypt since he was hurriedly summoned from Khartoum in January, 1900, by Lord Kitchener, to take part in the South African war.
Mr Walrond, Lord Milner's private secret ary, who has been visiting Cairo, left yesterday for South Africa.
The Financial Adviser and Mr. H N. Bowdon-Smith returned from Khartoum yesterday.

The latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel include Lady Londesborough, who arrived by the "Bremen,” Mr. Beadleston, Col. and Mme. R. de Planta, Hon. Mrs. Ronald Greville, Dr. and Mme. Aufachlaeger, Prof, and Mrs. D Vail, Mr. William McEwan, Mr. and Mrs. C. B. Burr, Miss M. Beardsley, Mias J. T. Sullivan, Mr. Edgar Anderson, and Mr. J. W. Wyatt.
Dr. John Garner has been promoted from assistant inspector to inspector of the Sanitary Department.
Kaimakam Patterson Bey, Sub-Commandant of the Cairo City Police, has been granted two months' leave, dating from Sunday.

The following passengers left Cairo for the Nile by the P. S. "Amenartas" yesterday; Mrs. Colls and friend, Dr. John and Mrs. Adcock, Mr. W. H. Sharpe, Mrs. Fred Sharpe, Mr. R. Thompson, Mrs. Ewart, Miss Doweling, Mrs. Pitt, Mrs. Poole, Mrs. Henry Wild, Miss
R. D. Wild, Mrs. and Miss Bagshaw.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: La semaine avait bien débuté, avec tendance marquée à la hausse, lorsque toutrà-ooup l'apris#-midi du 19, une réaction s'est produite, causée par les réalisations et les nouvelles politiquw inquiétantes. Les dépéchas d'hier ont fait dégénérer le recul en vraie débandade.

Trop vite oublieux, en effet, de la débâcle récente, certains spéculateurs, entraînés par la hausse, avaient pris dee positions intenables pour leurs faibles moyens. Aussi, quand la réaction est arrivée, ont-ils dû se retirer. Un petit parti baissier fort bruyant s’est organisé et, profitant d'un oôté de l'extrême resserve des acheteurs et de l’autre des réalisation» et de l'incertitude du marché, il a réussi, an partie au moins, à casser Isa prix. La valeur la plus éprouvée sous oa rapport a été la National Bank ; elle avait aussi été la plus favorisée ; elle avait haussé de prés de 2 £ 1/2 en deux jours.

On avait voulu marcher trop vite. Au fond, pourtant, la situation n'est pas mauvaise, si l'on considere qu'il n’existe presque pas da position de fin du mois, le petit publio ayant de ou réaliser ou se défaire avec perte. L'avenii est donc asses not. Les détenteurs qui restée sont pour la plupart dee capitalistes an état d< soutenir le choc d’une forte baisse, sans trop m laisser impressionner. 11 va sans dire que si les bourses de Paris et de Londres sont fortement affectées, on en ressentira ici le oontre-ooup, au moins dans une certaine mesure. En tout cas, on espère, aussitôt le calme rétabli, qu'une bonne reprise aura heu, ru l'abondanoe manifeste do capitaux sur cotre place. Un fait symptomatique de oette richesse est l'expédition faite en Europe samedi dernier par une banque locale de un million de livres sterling ; il wt très rare, en effet, qu’en pareille saison on expédie du numéraire à l'étranger ; c'est presque toujours le contraire qui a lieu. ^

La National Bank a eu, on peut le dire, les honneurs de la semaine. Elle a passé de 24 1/f i 26 1/2 pour retomber hier soir en cloture f 24 1346 La Nouvelle Emission a suivi h même mouvement et clôturé ferme à 23 7/8, Le chiffre des transactions a atteint plusieurs milliers de titras par jour.
L'Agricole, qui était aussi ferme au début a 10 1/16, a atteint 10 13/16 pour finir à 1( acheteurs, en assez bonne tendance.
De 14 1/2 la Delta Light tombe en clôtun à 14 3/16. La Deferred est à 16 SL sans aflai-res.
Les Privilégiées Tramways d’Alexandrie onf fluctué entre 143 1/2 et 146. Elles clôturent acheteurs à 144. Les Dividendes sont au prix
de 360 — 365 nominal.
La Ramleh Railway débutai 8 7/16, fléchit i 8 1/8 et reprend a 8 1/4.

D’importantes affaires ont eu lieu en Sait & Soda, mais le mouvement ne se dessinera sur cette valeur qu'après l’assemblée du 27 courant En attendant le cours suit les fluo--tuations générales ; il tombe (le 43 i 89/9, pour reprendre légèrement vers la fin à 40/3 ferme.
En Nungovich nous fléchissons do 10 1/8 i 9 9/16, pour remonter en clôture i 9 3/4. La rumeur d'une fusion a été officiellement démentie.
L'Anglo-American Nile recule de 5 5/16 à 5 acheteurs.
La Crown Brewery u’a pas présenté une grande animation durant cette semaine Le cours a fluctué de 216 i 220 pour clôturer
De son côté, la Brassorie des Pyramides débuta i 126, monta i 130 et réactionne i 128.
La Banque d'Athènes suit la baisse générale. Après avoir touché un moment 125 1/2, elle fléchit i 118 1/2 pour finir hier soir i 119 1/2.
Contrairement aux autres valeurs, les Baux du Caire gagnent du terrain : après avoir fléchi un instant de 1,105 à 1,070, elles reprennent bientôt à 1,120 en clôture.
Les Eaux d'Alexandrie restant délaissées à 15 7/8.
Commo les Eaux du Caire, la‘Khédivial Mail donne lieu à une bonne demande et remonta de ce fait de 3 13/16 à 4 1/8 acheteurs. L'Ordinary hausse également da 11 à 13 shelling.’.
Les Obligations Crédit Foncier réactionnent de 300 à 296 en clôture.
Los Markets fléchissent aussi de 23/9 à 23 vendeurs.
Une grande activité a régné sur Is Corpora tion of Wostern Egypt (Oasis). Le prix a subi do violentas fluctuations ; de 1 3/4 il a haussé jusqu’à 2 7/16, pour retomber aussitôt à 1 9/16 acheteurs.
(Aujourd'hui, midi et demie).
Ce matin, sur d’importants rachats, les cours de certaines valeurs regagnent en partie le ter rain perdu.

Ainsi la Banque Nationalo remonta de 24 3/4 à 25 1/2, l’Agricole de 10 à 10 1/2, laDaira de 21 3/4 à 22 1/16, la Nungovich die 9 3/4 à 9 13/16, la Delta Light de 14 3/16 à 14 5/16, et les Privilégiées Tramways de 144 à 145 1/2.
La hausse de la Khédivial Mail atteint 4 1/4.
Le marché en général est plus ferme et la tendance meilleure.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Manage ment. Moderate charges. Patronised by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.
